title: DCCC: Valadao Refuses to Push Bipartisan Immigration Reform - Again
body:
The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee issued the following news release:

Congressman David Valadao wants the people of California to believe that he's fighting for immigration, but when 
push comes to shove, he just keeps standing in the way of bipartisan reform.

The latest example: Congressman Valadao is still refusing to sign on to a petition that would allow an immediate 
vote on immigration reform - all because he refuses to cross party lines and work with Democrats. In fact, his 
office told CNN (http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2014/03/24/house-democrats-to-try-to-force-a-vote-on-
immigration/) that "a discharge petition is legislatively not productive [] if they had 218 votes for the bill, this 
wouldn't be an issue."

"Time and again, Congressman Valadao has frustrated the Central Valley on immigration reform by refusing to 
push to fix our broken immigration system," said Tyrone Gayle of the Democratic Congressional Campaign 
Committee. "Congressman Valadao and House Republicans are blocking a vote on comprehensive immigration 
reform - even though they know it has the votes to pass. Central Valley families won't forget Congressman 
Valadao's record of inaction and history of anti-immigrant actions in November."

BACKGROUND:

Congressman Valadao Opposed Signing Discharge Petition Allowing Immediate Vote on Bipartisan House 
Immigration Bill. In March 2014, Anna Raquel Vetter, Valadao's communications director, said that Valadao was 
opposed to signing a discharge petition that would bring the House comprehensive immigration reform bill to an 
immediate vote. If 218 of 435 House members sign the discharge petition, it will force a vote on the comprehensive 
immigration bill."But a discharge petition is legislatively not productive if they had 218 votes for the bill, this 
wouldn't be an issue," Vetter said on behalf of Valadao. [CNN, 3/24/14 
(http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2014/03/24/house-democrats-to-try-to-force-a-vote-on-immigration/)]

Despite Previously Gloating about his Co-sponsorship of the House Bill. In October 2013, Valadao co-sponsored 
the House comprehensive immigration reform bill and released a statement promoting his support. "By 
supporting H.R. 15 I am strengthening my message: Addressing immigration reform in the House cannot wait I 
am serious about making real progress and will remain committed to doing whatever it takes to repair our broken 
immigration system," Valadao wrote. [H.R. 15, Co-sponsored 10/30/13 (http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-
congress/house-
bill/15/cosponsors?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22hr15%22%5D%2C%22party%22%3A%22Republican%22
%7D); Huffington Post, 10/30/13 (           http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/30/david-valadao-
immigration_n_4178844.html)]


Valadao Opposed Signing Discharge Petition for Bipartisan Senate Immigration Bill. In February 2014, Valadao 
opposed Sen. Chuck Schumer's proposal to use a discharge petition to bring the Senate comprehensive 
immigration reform bill to a vote. "No, there's just no way," Valadao said. Tal Eslick, Valadao's chief of staff, 
added the following: "Congressman Valadao does not believe there is sufficient support among House Republicans 
to support a discharge petition related to the Senate immigration bill, nor does he believe that is the best path 
forward." [Politico, 2/28/14 (http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/republicans-immigration-reform-discharge-
petition-104080.html); 91.3 HQR, 2/13/14 (           http://whqr.org/post/takeover-hopes-fade-house-democrats-
remain-upbeat)]

Valadao Said "He Did Not Have Plans to Increase Pressure on His Republican Colleagues" on Immigration 
Reform. In September 2013, the New York Times reported that "While Mr. Valadao said he did not have plans to 
increase pressure on his Republican colleagues, other local leaders have been more willing to openly voice 
criticism" to push House Republicans to take up immigration reform. [New York Times, 9/07/13 
(http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/08/us/politics/house-republicans-in-california-find-a-struggle-on-
immigration.html?pagewanted=2&_r=1&)]

Valadao Voted to Jeopardize Dreamers. In 2014, Valadao voted for the Executive Needs to Faithfully Observe and 
Respect Congressional Enactments (ENFORCE) of the Law Act of 2014, which the Huffington Post reported "could 
end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals policy that keeps the [Dreamers] people from being deported." The 
bill passed 233 to 181. [H.R. 4138, Vote #124 (http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2014/roll124.xml), 3/12/14; Huffington 
Post, 3/12/14 (           http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/12/house-
immigration_n_4950425.html?&ncid=tweetlnkushpmg00000016)]

Voted Against CA DREAM Act Pt. 1: Allowing Private Scholarships for Undocumented Immigrants. In 2011, 
Valadao voted against a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants to receive privately funded scholarships to 
attend the state's public colleges and universities. The bill passed the Assembly, 51-22, and was signed into law. 
[AB 130, 5/05/11; Reuters, 7/25/11 (http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/25/us-usa-california-dream-
idUSTRE76O6FV20110725)]

Voted Against CA DREAM Act Pt. 2: Allowing State Financial Aid for Undocumented Immigrants. In 2011, Valadao 
voted against a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants to qualify for state financial aid to attend the state's 
public colleges and universities. The bill passed the Assembly, 48-27, and was signed into law. [AB 131, 9/02/11; 
Los Angeles Times, 10/09/11]
